column5: "The Affen’s apish look has been described many ways. They’ve been called “monkey dogs” and “ape terriers.” The French say diablotin moustachu (“mustached little devil”)
column6: and Star Wars fans argue whether they look more like Wookies or Ewoks.Standing less than a foot tall
column7: these sturdy terrier-like dogs approach life with great confidence. “This isn’t a breed you train
column8: ” a professional dog handler tells us
column9: “He’s like a human. You befriend him.” The dense
column10: harsh coat is described as “neat but shaggy” and comes in several colors; the gait is light and confident. They can be willful and domineering
column11: but mostly Affens are loyal
column12: affectionate
column13: and always entertaining. Affen people say they love being owned by their little monkey dogs. The Affenpinscher: loyal
column14: curious
column15: and famously amusing; this almost-human toy dog is fearless out of all proportion to his size. As with all great comedians
column16: it’s the Affenpinscher’s apparent seriousness of purpose that makes his antics all the more amusing."
column17: "Confident

column5: "The Afghan Hound is an ancient breed
column6: his whole appearance one of dignity and aloofness – his eyes gazing into the distance as if in memory of ages past. An intelligent and independent mind
column7: his whole appearance one of dignity and style. To his own he is devoted and loyal with a charming and lively personality. The Afghan Hound is an athlete capable of immense speed and requires a large fenced in yard and exercise daily.Since ancient times
column8: Afghan Hounds have been famous for their elegant beauty. But the thick
column9: silky
column10: flowing coat that is the breed’s crowning glory isn’t just for show — it served as protection from the harsh climate in mountainous regions where Afghans originally earned their keep. Beneath the Afghan’s glamorous exterior is a powerful
column11: agile hound — standing as high as 27 inches at the shoulder — built for a long day’s hunt. Their huge paw-pads acted as shock absorbers on their homeland’s punishing terrain.The Afghan Hound is a special breed for special people. A breed expert writes
column12: “It’s not the breed for all would-be dog owners
column13: but where the dog and owner combination is right
column14: no animal can equal the Afghan Hound as a pet.” The Afghan Hound is an aloof and dignified aristocrat of sublime beauty. Despite his regal appearance
column15: he is known for his profound loyalty
column16: sensitive nature
column17: and absolute love for those he calls his own."

column5: "The Airedale Terrier is the largest of all terrier breeds. Males stand about 23 inches at the shoulder
column6: females a little less. The dense
column7: wiry coat is tan with black markings. Long
column8: muscular legs give Airedales a regal lift in their bearing
column9: and the long head—with its sporty beard and mustache
column11: and neatly folded ears—conveys a keen intelligence. Airedales are the very picture of an alert and willing terrier—only bigger. And
column12: like his smaller cousins in the terrier family
column13: he can be bold
column14: determined
column15: and stubborn. Airedales are docile and patient with kids but won’t back down when protecting hearth and home. Thanks to their famous do-it-all attitude
column16: Airedales excel in all kinds of sports and family activities. His size
column17: strength
column18: and unflagging spirit have earned the Airedale Terrier the nickname “The King of Terriers.” The Airedale stands among the world’s most versatile dog breeds and has distinguished himself as hunter

column5: "Akitas are burly
column6: heavy-boned spitz-type dogs of imposing stature. Standing 24 to 28 inches at the shoulder
column7: Akitas have a dense coat that comes in several colors
column8: including white. The head is broad and massive
column9: and is balanced in the rear by a full
column10: curled-over tail. The erect ears and dark
column11: shining eyes contribute to an expression of alertness
column12: a hallmark of the breed.Akitas are quiet
column13: fastidious dogs. Wary of strangers and often intolerant of other animals
column14: Akitas will gladly share their silly
column15: affectionate side with family and friends. They thrive on human companionship. The large
column16: independent-thinking Akita is hardwired for protecting those they love. They must be well socialized from birth with people and other dogs. Akitas are muscular
column17: double-coated dogs of ancient Japanese lineage famous for their dignity
column19: and loyalty. In their native land
column20: they are venerated as family protectors and symbols of good health

column6: heavy-boned spitz-type dogs of imposing stature. Standing 24 to 28 inches at the shoulder
column7: Akitas have a dense coat that comes in several colors
column8: including white. The head is broad and massive
column9: and is balanced in the rear by a full
column10: curled-over tail. The erect ears and dark
column11: shining eyes contribute to an expression of alertness
column12: a hallmark of the breed.Akitas are quiet
column13: fastidious dogs. Wary of strangers and often intolerant of other animals
column14: Akitas will gladly share their silly
column15: affectionate side with family and friends. They thrive on human companionship. The large
column16: independent-thinking Akita is hardwired for protecting those they love. They must be well socialized from birth with people and other dogs. Akitas are muscular
column17: double-coated dogs of ancient Japanese lineage famous for their dignity
column19: and loyalty. In their native land
column20: they are venerated as family protectors and symbols of good health

column5: "The American Bulldog is a descendant of the English Bulldog. It is believed that the bulldog was in America as early as the 17th century. They came to the United States in the 1800s
column6: with immigrants who brought their working bulldogs with them. Small farmers and ranchers used this all-around working dog for many tasks including farm guardians
column7: stock dogs
column8: and catch dogs. The breed largely survived
column9: particularly in the southern states
column10: due to its ability to bring down and catch feral pigs.The breed we know as the American Bulldog was originally known by many different names before the name American Bulldog became the standard. In different parts of the South he was known as the White English Southern Bulldog
column11: but most commonly just “bulldog.” The breed was not called a bulldog because of a certain look
column12: but because they did real bulldog work. Breed Contact InformationKatrina HuffmasterPhone:  850-519-3089 American Bulldogs are a well-balanced athletic dog that demonstrate great strength
column13: endurance
column14: agility
column15: and a friendly attitude. Historically
column16: they were bred to be a utility dog used for working the farm."
column17: "Loyal

column5: "The American Eskimo Dog comes in three sizes—standard
column6: miniature
column7: and toy—standing as tall as 19 inches at the shoulder or as short as 9 inches. Distinctive traits include a dense
column8: sparkling white coat with a lion-like ruff around the chest and shoulders; a smiling face
column9: with black nose
column11: and eye-rims that convey a keen
column12: intelligent expression; and a plumed tail carried over the back. Some Eskies have markings with the delicious color name “biscuit cream.” They move with a bold and agile gait.Eskies are social animals and can develop problem behaviors when neglected or undertrained—they insist on being part of family life. Among the most trainable of breeds
column13: the clever
column14: kid-friendly Eskie practically invented the phrase “eager to please.” The American Eskimo Dog combines striking good looks with a quick and clever mind in a total brains-and-beauty package. Neither shy nor aggressive
column15: Eskies are always alert and friendly
column16: though a bit conservative when making new friends."

column5: "American Water Spaniels are muscular midsize gundogs
column6: not flashy in looks or performance
column7: and recognizable by a luscious brown coat that is either tightly curled or wavy. Bred to work the icy waters and marshy banks of the Great Lakes region
column8: these spaniels are ideally outfitted for the job: The coat is dense and waterproof
column9: the feet are thickly padded
column11: and the body is small enough for the dog to hop in and out of a skiff without rocking the boat. The breed’s admirers describe a merry
column12: intelligent
column13: and versatile spaniel suited to a variety of dog sports. As hunters
column14: they combine the working traits of spaniels and retrievers. The key to the American Water Spaniel’s happiness is activity
column15: especially alongside their adored human. An underemployed dog can be barky and destructive. The American Water Spaniel
column16: native to the lake country of the upper Midwest
column17: is an upbeat
column18: outdoorsy athlete who loves to hunt and swim. They are known to be happy
column21: though aloof with strangers and a bit stubborn."

column5: "Standing between 17 to 20 inches at the shoulder
column6: the Australian Cattle Dog is a sturdy
column7: hard-muscled herder of strength and agility. The ACD is born with a white coat that turns blue-gray or red. Both coat varieties feature distinctive mottling or specking patterns. ACDs have immense work drive and excel at hunting
column8: chasing
column9: and
column11: moving livestock. Their boundless energy and supple gait make them excellent running partners.ACDs are true-blue loyal
column12: famously smart
column13: ever alert
column14: and wary of strangers. If an ACD isn’t challenged
column15: he easily becomes bored and gets into mischief. It is recommended that ACD owners participate with their dog in some work
column16: sport
column17: or regular exercise to keep him mentally and physically fit. The compact but muscular Australian Cattle Dog
column18: also called Blue Heeler or Queensland Heeler
column19: is related to Australia’s famous wild dog
column20: the Dingo. These resilient herders are intelligent enough to routinely outsmart their owners."

column7: hard-muscled herder of strength and agility. The ACD is born with a white coat that turns blue-gray or red. Both coat varieties feature distinctive mottling or specking patterns. ACDs have immense work drive and excel at hunting
column8: chasing
column9: and
column11: moving livestock. Their boundless energy and supple gait make them excellent running partners.ACDs are true-blue loyal
column12: famously smart
column13: ever alert
column14: and wary of strangers. If an ACD isn’t challenged
column15: he easily becomes bored and gets into mischief. It is recommended that ACD owners participate with their dog in some work
column16: sport
column17: or regular exercise to keep him mentally and physically fit. The compact but muscular Australian Cattle Dog
column18: also called Blue Heeler or Queensland Heeler
column19: is related to Australia’s famous wild dog
column20: the Dingo. These resilient herders are intelligent enough to routinely outsmart their owners."

column5: "As a herding dog
column6: the Australian Kelpie is intensely loyal and devoted to duty. He has a natural instinct and aptitude for working in sheep
column7: whether it be in open fields or enclosed yards. This breed originated from Collie type dogs imported from Scotland
column8: but was developed to withstand the harsh heat and dry conditions of the vast open spaces of Australia. The Australian Kelpie is a lithe
column9: active dog
column10: capable of untiring work. He is extremely intelligent
column11: alert
column12: and eager with unlimited energy."

column5: "The Australian Shepherd
column6: the cowboy’s herding dog of choice
column7: is a medium-sized worker with a keen
column8: penetrating gaze in the eye. Aussie coats offer different looks
column9: including merle (a mottled pattern with contrasting shades of blue or red). In all ways
column10: they’re the picture of rugged and agile movers of stock. Aussies exhibit an irresistible impulse to herd
column11: anything: birds
column12: dogs
column13: kids. This strong work drive can make Aussies too much dog for a sedentary pet owner. Aussies are remarkably intelligent
column14: quite capable of hoodwinking an unsuspecting novice owner. In short
column15: this isn’t the pet for everyone. But if you’re looking for a brainy
column16: tireless
column17: and trainable partner for work or sport
column18: your search might end here. The Australian Shepherd
column21: is one of those “only in America” stories: a European breed perfected in California by way of Australia. Fixtures on the rodeo circuit
column22: they are closely associated with the cowboy life."

column5: "Australian Terriers are small but sturdy
column6: self-confident terriers known for a longish torso
column7: distinctive coat furnishings around the neck and forequarters
column8: and a topknot of soft
column9: silky hair that contrasts in texture with an otherwise harsh coat. A long neck lends a dash of elegance to this rough-and-ready terrier
column10: and the dark eyes sparkle with a keen intelligence. Coat colors are blue-and-tan
column11: or solid red or sandy. Aussies move with the free and easy gait of a working dog. They are alert watchdogs and said to be quick studies when training. True terriers
column12: Aussies love digging
column13: and the urge to chase small
column14: furry critters has never left them. Not always a great fit in multi-dog households
column15: Aussies want you all to themselves. The diminutive Australian Terrier is plucky
column16: spirited
column17: and smart—how did they fit so much dog into such a bitty package? Upbeat and lively
column18: the self-assured Aussie approaches life with plenty of the old-time terrier curiosity and grit."

column5: "Basenjis are small
column6: graceful hounds standing 16 or 17 inches at the shoulder. They are recognizable by their glistening short coat
column7: tightly curled tail
column8: and wrinkled forehead and expressive almond-shaped eyes that convey a variety of subtle
column9: humanlike emotions.Basenjis are a lovely sight at a standstill but more impressive yet at a fast trot
column11: smooth strides of a mini-racehorse. And yes
column12: it’s true
column13: they don’t bark
column14: but they make their feelings known with an odd sound described as something between a chortle and a yodel. Basenjis are fastidious and will groom themselves like cats. This has been called a “cult breed”—small in numbers
column15: but those lucky enough to own one do so with singular devotion. The Basenji
column16: Africa’s “Barkless Dog
column17: ” is a compact
column18: sweet-faced hunter of intelligence and poise. They are unique and beguiling pets
column19: best for owners who can meet their exercise needs and the challenge of training this catlike canine."

column5: basset hound
column6: "The Basset Hound stands no higher than 14 inches at the shoulder but
column7: with his remarkably heavy bone
column8: powerful little legs
column9: and massive paws
column10: he possesses big-dog strength and stamina. Bassets are famous for a large
column11: domed head that features extremely long
column12: velvety ears
column13: mournful eyes
column14: and a wrinkled brow
column15: which give the breed the look of a sad clown. Built more for endurance than speed
column16: the Basset moves in a deliberate but effortless manner. The breed’s scenting ability is uncanny; it’s said that among dogs only the Bloodhound’s nose is more accurate. Mild and agreeable at home
column17: the Basset is stubborn on the trail and barks in a loud

column11: as befit dogs built to work hard for their feed. A breed hallmark is the proud carriage of the head. Coat colors range from a rich fawn to mahogany. The black ears and mask accentuate bright
column12: questioning eyes the color of dark Belgian chocolate.If you have ever seen a Mal perform an obedience routine

column5: "The stirring silhouette of a Belgian Sheepdog conveys both elegance and muscular determination. A handsome feature of the breed is the exceedingly proud carriage of the head and neck. A male might stand 26 inches at the shoulder; females are smaller. The dark eyes sparkle with a questioning intelligence
column6: and the black coat is abundant
column7: from the neck’s “collarette” to the “breeches” of the hindquarters. In all ways
column8: Belgian Sheepdogs are bright-eyed and bushy-tailed.In any sport or activity
column9: a Belgian will always give 100 percent. In turn
column10: owners tend to form a special bond with their eager workaholics. As one devotee puts it
column11: Belgians “inspire such intense loyalty because they themselves live and love with such great passion.” The Belgian Sheepdog is a highly trainable herder whose versatility and intelligence is the stuff of canine legend. This is a breed built for hard work
column12: and plenty of it. These sensitive souls crave human companionship and abhor neglect."
column13: "Bright
column14: Watchful
column15: Serious-Minded"

column5: "The Belgian Tervuren is characterized by a straight and abundant coat
column6: an elegant but muscular frame
column7: a proudly carried head
column8: an alert and intelligent demeanor
column9: and an insatiable work drive. The Tervuren’s coat furnishings
column10: like the sporty “collarette” around the neck
column11: are more profuse on males
column12: who run larger than females.“Their intelligence and high activity level can be a challenge for the less creative individual who may not understand the breed’s need to work
column13: ” warns one longtime owner. But don’t get the idea that Tervurens are grim
column14: mechanical worker drones. In fact
column15: this breed takes real delight in their ability to master any task
column16: and owners say a mischievous sense of humor is at work whenever Tervurens outsmart their beloved human. The elegant
column17: agile Belgian Tervuren is a bright and self-assured herding dog of medium size
column18: known to be affectionate and possessive with loved ones. Lots of hard work and challenging play is heaven for this tireless

column9: clear white

column5: "Black and Tans have an amazingly sensitive nose
column6: long
column7: velvety ears
column8: and a sweet disposition. The coal-black coat features rich tan accents
column9: including the distinctive “pumpkin seeds” above keenly expressive eyes. These are big
column10: strong hounds: A good-size male can stand 27 inches at the shoulder and cover ground with effortless
column11: eager strides.B&Ts are sociable hounds. A lonely B&T will serenade the neighborhood with loud
column12: mournful “music.” B&Ts can keep pace with the most active family
column13: but they also can hog the sofa for hours on end. Hounds will be hounds: A passing squirrel can arouse B&T prey drive in no time flat
column14: so a strong leash and sturdy fence are must-haves. B&Ts might be too much hound for the lifestyle of every owner. Large
column15: athletic hunters who work nights
column16: Black and Tan Coonhounds are friendly
column17: easygoing hounds who love company. They are snoozy by the fireside but tenacious when on the trail of the wily raccoon. This hound is a real American original."

column8: and a sweet disposition. The coal-black coat features rich tan accents
column9: including the distinctive “pumpkin seeds” above keenly expressive eyes. These are big
column10: strong hounds: A good-size male can stand 27 inches at the shoulder and cover ground with effortless
column11: eager strides.B&Ts are sociable hounds. A lonely B&T will serenade the neighborhood with loud
column12: mournful “music.” B&Ts can keep pace with the most active family
column13: but they also can hog the sofa for hours on end. Hounds will be hounds: A passing squirrel can arouse B&T prey drive in no time flat
column14: so a strong leash and sturdy fence are must-haves. B&Ts might be too much hound for the lifestyle of every owner. Large
column15: athletic hunters who work nights
column16: Black and Tan Coonhounds are friendly
column17: easygoing hounds who love company. They are snoozy by the fireside but tenacious when on the trail of the wily raccoon. This hound is a real American original."

column5: "What’s the word we’re looking for? Imposing? Massive? Majestic? How about just plain “big.” This brawny guard dog of the Siberian steppes can tip the scales at 140 pounds and stand as high as 30 inches at the shoulder. They’re much taller when the huge
column6: brick-shaped head is considered. The tousled
column7: all-black coat is warm enough to allow BRTs to patrol some of the coldest habitable places on earth. The old expression “He moves well for a big guy” applies to this nimble-footed giant. The Black Russian Terrier is a large
column8: immensely powerful worker of heavy bone and coarse all-black coat. BRTs are known for their courage
column9: confidence
column10: and intelligence. Bred to guard and protect
column11: they are naturally aloof with strangers."

column5: "Blueticks are speedy and compact nocturnal hunters named for the mottled (or “ticked”) black-and-blue pattern of the glossy coat. A large male can top out at 27 inches and 80 pounds; females are smaller. Blueticks are well-muscled but sleek and racy
column6: never chunky or clumsy. The baying
column7: bawling
column8: and chopping bark of Blueticks might be cacophonous to some
column9: but to coon hunters it’s the music of the night.The droopy-eared charm of Blueticks is irresistible. They crave affection and are deeply devoted to those who provide it. Blueticks have tremendous prey drive. Neglected
column10: underemployed coonhounds with no outlet for their hardwired impulses can develop problem behaviors
column11: like serenading the neighbors with loud
column12: mournful “music.” The sleekly beautiful Bluetick Coonhound is a sweet and affectionate charmer who might enjoy snoozing in the shade
column13: but in pursuit of quarry he is relentless
column14: bold
column15: and single-minded. His off-the-charts prey drive must be channeled."
column16: "Smart
column17: Devoted

column5: "Borzoi are large
column6: elegant sighthounds. A mature male stands at least 28 inches at the shoulder and weighs 75 to 105 pounds. Females will be smaller. Beneath the luxurious silky coat
column7: Borzoi construction follows the ancient Greyhound template. Once known as the Russian Wolfhound
column8: Borzoi were bred to be swift and tough enough to pursue and pin their ferocious lupine quarry.In their quiet
column9: catlike way they can be stubborn
column10: and training is best accomplished with patience
column11: consistency
column12: and good humor. Affectionate family dogs
column13: Borzoi are nonetheless a bit too dignified to wholeheartedly enjoy a lot of roughhousing. The sight of a cat or squirrel on the run will quickly stir their pursuit instinct
column14: and fenced-in running room is a must. Among the most impressively beautiful of all dogs
column15: the aristocratic Borzoi is cherished for his calm
column16: agreeable temperament. In full stride
column17: he is a princely package of strength
column19: and glamour flying by at 35 to 40 miles per hour."

column10: and training is best accomplished with patience
column11: consistency
column12: and good humor. Affectionate family dogs
column13: Borzoi are nonetheless a bit too dignified to wholeheartedly enjoy a lot of roughhousing. The sight of a cat or squirrel on the run will quickly stir their pursuit instinct
column14: and fenced-in running room is a must. Among the most impressively beautiful of all dogs
column15: the aristocratic Borzoi is cherished for his calm
column16: agreeable temperament. In full stride
column17: he is a princely package of strength
column19: and glamour flying by at 35 to 40 miles per hour."

column5: "Boston Terriers are compact
column6: short-tailed
column7: well-balanced little dogs weighing no more than 25 pounds. The stylish “tuxedo” coat can be white and either black
column8: brindle
column9: or seal (black with a red cast when viewed in sun or bright light). The head is square
column11: and the large
column12: round eyes can shine with kindness
column13: curiosity
column14: or mischief. Ever alert to their surroundings
column15: Bostons move with a jaunty
column16: rhythmic step.It’s a safe bet that a breed named for a city—the Havanese or Brussels Griffon
column17: for instance—will make an excellent urban pet. Bostons are no exception: they are sturdy but portable
column19: and always up for a brisk walk to the park or outdoor cafe. A bright dog with a natural gift for comedy
column20: the dapper Bostonian is a steady source of smiles. The Boston Terrier is a lively little companion recognized by his tight tuxedo jacket
column22: and the friendly glow in his big
column23: round eyes. His impeccable manners have earned him the nickname “The American Gentleman.”"

column11: and keen intelligence endear them to dog lovers the world over.The Bouvier work ethic must be accommodated

column5: "A well-made Boxer in peak condition is an awesome sight. A male can stand as high as 25 inches at the shoulder; females run smaller. Their muscles ripple beneath a short
column6: tight-fitting coat. The dark brown eyes and wrinkled forehead give the face an alert
column7: curious look. The coat can be fawn or brindle
column8: with white markings. Boxers move like the athletes they are named for: smooth and graceful
column9: with a powerful forward thrust.Boxers are upbeat and playful. Their patience and protective nature have earned them a reputation as a great dog with children. They take the jobs of watchdog and family guardian seriously and will meet threats fearlessly. Boxers do best when exposed to a lot of people and other animals in early puppyhood. Loyalty
column11: intelligence
column12: work ethic
column13: and good looks: Boxers are the whole doggy package. Bright and alert
column14: sometimes silly
column15: but always courageous
column16: the Boxer has been among America’s most popular dog breeds for a very long time."

column5: "Briards are herders known for a wavy coat of either gray
column6: tawny
column7: or black
column8: and an impressive head topped by a peek-a-boo hairdo parted naturally in the middle. A luxurious beard and eyebrows accentuate an expression described as “frank and questioning.” Standing between 22 and 27 inches at the shoulder
column9: Briards are burly and rugged but move with a nimble-footed gait.They possess traits common to many other herders: trainability
column11: a protective eye toward family (especially kids
column12: whom they regard as their flock)
column13: and wariness with outsiders. These are large
column14: tireless dogs—it is said that just two or three Briards can handle 700 head of sheep—and novice owners might be overwhelmed by their work drive and zest for life. The Briard packs so much loyalty
column15: love
column16: and spirit into its ample frame that it's often described as a ""heart wrapped in fur."" The dashing good looks of these muscular Frenchmen radiate a distinct aura of Gallic romance and elegance."
column17: "Confident

column5: "Brittanys are smaller than setters but leggier than spaniels
column6: standing about 20 inches at the shoulder. Their beautiful
column7: boldly patterned coat comes in combinations of white and vivid orange and liver (reddish-brown). They are rugged and strong but smooth
column8: clean
column9: and quick afoot. The face has the “softness” prized by bird-dog lovers; high-set ears convey the breed’s essential eagerness.The zeal and versatility that make Brittanys peerless hunters can be channeled into dog sports. Obedience
column11: flyball
column12: dock diving—you name it
column13: this trainable breed is up for it. The Brittany is a nice fit for those seeking an all-purpose hunting partner
column14: a dog-sport teammate
column15: or a companion in sync with an upbeat
column16: outdoorsy family life. Sportsmen on both sides of the Atlantic cherish the agile
column17: energetic Brittany as a stylish and versatile gundog. Bright and eager at home
column19: Brittanys require a lot of exercises

column5: "With this breed
column6: you get a big personality in a 5-to-15-pound package. One look into his big
column7: human-like eyes
column8: and you’ll be smitten. Griffs come in four colors—red
column9: black-and-reddish-brown (called belge)
column11: and black—and in smooth coats (like a Pug) or rough coats (like a Schnauzer). Their black muzzle and whiskers earned them the nickname “bearded dogs” in old folk songs.The Griff’s big black eyes—described as “almost human”—coupled with a fringed beard and mustache covering his short muzzle
column12: gives him the air of a worldly
column13: French-speaking philosopher. The Griff’s body is thickset and sturdy
column14: and he moves with the purposeful trot of a fellow who knows what he wants.Griffs are alert
column15: sociable
column16: and easily trained. Although playful and energetic
column17: their small size and sensitive nature make them a poor choice as roughhousing playmates for kids. They have a low threshold for loneliness and will stick close to their special human
column18: providing years of love and laughter. Tipping the scales at no more than 12 pounds
column19: this human-like toy of complex character has enough personality for 10 ordinary dogs. A sensitive companion for discerning grownups

column5: "Bull Terriers are robust
column6: big-boned terriers who move with a jaunty stride suggesting agility and power. The breed’s hallmark is a long
column7: egg-shaped head with erect and pointed ears

column5: "The Cairn’s unique qualities
column6: called “Cairnishness
column7: ” include a short
column8: wide head and a free-moving
column9: short-legged body that exudes strength but not heaviness
column10: topping out at about 10 inches high and about 15 inches long. The double coat is harsh and wiry on top and downy beneath. A Cairn presents as a small
column11: shaggy
column12: alert dog
column13: with head
column14: tail
column15: and ears up
column16: and eyes shining with intelligence.A British breed club promotes Cairns as the “best little pal in the world.” Cairns are small enough for a lap-top snuggle and sturdy enough for a good romp on the lawn. They do best with lots of close family contact. For owners who cherish the terrier qualities of gameness
column17: independent thinking
column19: no other breed will do. Cairn Terriers are happy
column20: busy little earthdogs originally bred to fearlessly root out foxes and other small
column21: furred prey in the rocky Scottish countryside. Curious and alert
column22: Cairns like having a place where they can explore and dig."

column5: "Canaan Dogs are lean
column6: bushy-tailed dogs standing 19 to 24 inches at the shoulder. The coat is straight and harsh
column7: and comes in various colors and patterns. Erect
column8: expressive ears and dark almond eyes convey an inquisitive expression. Canaans move at a brisk
column9: natural trot. They are rugged
column11: and apparently tireless
column12: making them a nice fit for hikers and runners.Canaans are clever
column13: confident
column14: and territorial. They will end up “owning” passive owners who haven’t establish themselves as top dog in the family pack. Early training and socialization are key. When positive methods are applied
column15: these ancient wonder-dogs train beautifully. Agility
column16: obedience
column17: herding trials
column18: and sentry duty are a few outlets for their work ethic. One of the AKC's oldest breeds
column19: the Canaan Dog is the national dog of Israel. This quick
column20: medium-sized pasture dog is docile with family
column21: aloof with strangers. The ever-alert Canaan is a vocal and persistent guardian of flock and home."

column6: low-set dogs with sturdy bone
column7: short legs
column8: and a deep chest
column9: Cardigans are powerful workers of deceptive speed and grace. Cardis can weigh anywhere from 25 to 34 pounds
column10: with females at the lower end of the scale. They come in several coat colors
column11: from red to the popular blue-merle pattern. The quickest way to distinguish Cardis from their cousins
column12: Pembroke Welsh Corgis
column13: is to check out the hindquarters: Cardigans have tails; Pembrokes do not.Cardis are trainable
column14: faithful
column15: and vigilant guardians with a “big dog” bark. Well-socialized Cardis are especially fond of kids and agreeable with other pets. These athletic
column16: rugged herders have a love for the outdoors
column17: and they thrive on mental stimulation and physical activity. The Cardigan Welsh Corgi is a masterpiece of the breeder’s art: Every aspect of its makeup is perfectly suited to moving cattle
column18: and yet it is so congenial and sweet-faced that it would be a cherished companion even if it never did a day’s work."

column5: "The Cavalier’s all-around beauty
column6: regal grace
column7: and even temper mark him as one of dogdom’s noblemen. A toy spaniel no more than 13 inches high
column8: the Cavalier draws you in with his face: The sweet
column9: gentle
column11: round eyes is a breed hallmark. Another is the silky
column12: richly-colored coat that can be one of four distinct varieties.Cavaliers may be aristocrats
column13: but they gladly descend from their royal high horse for a backyard frolic or a squirrel chase. They get along nicely with children and other dogs. Adaptable Cavaliers do equally well with active owners and homebodies—they can be upbeat athletes or shameless couch potatoes
column14: depending on an owner’s lifestyle. The Cavalier King Charles Spaniel wears his connection to British history in his breed’s name. Cavaliers are the best of two worlds
column15: combining the gentle attentiveness of a toy breed with the verve and athleticism of a sporting spaniel."

column5: "Chessies are strong
column6: powerfully built gundogs standing anywhere from 21 to 26 inches at the shoulder. A male can weigh up to 80 pounds. The distinctive breed trait is a wavy coat that is oily to the touch. Chessies are solid-colored
column7: either chocolatey brown
column8: sedge
column9: or deadgrass
column10: with keen yellow-amber eyes that nicely complement the coat.Chessies are more emotionally complex than the usual gundog. Chessies take to training
column11: but they have a mind of their own and can tenaciously pursue their own path. They are protective of their humans and polite
column12: but not overtly friendly
column13: to strangers. Chessies make excellent watchdogs and are versatile athletes. A well-socialized Chessie is a confident companion and world-class hunting buddy. The Chesapeake Bay Retriever
column14: peerless duck dog of the Mid-Atlantic
column15: is an American original who embodies the classic traits of a good retriever: loyal
column16: upbeat
column17: affectionate
column18: and tireless. The Chessie is famous for his waterproof coat."

column17: an all-purpose dog of ancient China

column5: "Clumber Spaniels are powerful bird dogs of heavy bone
column6: built long and low
column7: with a massive head. They stand 17 to 20 inches; a small female might be 55 pounds
column8: and a large male could go 85 pounds. Built to push through thick cover in the field
column9: Clumber movement is nonetheless free and easy. The dense coat is primarily white
column10: with sparse lemon or orange markings.Clumbers are sweet and easygoing at home
column11: but these outdoorsy fellows can be relentless on scent. Smart and eager-to-please Clumbers respond well to training. Though a bit wary around strangers
column12: Clumbers are friendly dogs who bark only when they have something to say
column13: and so make indifferent watchdogs. They love swimming and fetching
column14: and are sturdy childhood playmates. A dignified and mellow hunting companion of kings
column15: the Clumber Spaniel is the largest of the AKC flushing spaniels. For those who can handle some shedding and drooling
column16: the amiable Clumber is an amusing best friend and a gentlemanly housemate."
column17: "Mellow

column5: "The Coton de Tulear (KO-Tone Dih TOO-Lay-ARE) is a small
column6: immensely charming dog standing between 9 and 11 inches high and weighing anywhere from 8 to 13 pounds. Cotons are known for a profuse white coat that is as soft as cotton (or
column7: as the French say
column8: “coton”). Their primary job is to provide amusement
column9: comfort
column10: and companionship.The bond between Cotons and their people is so tight that owners discuss it in human terms. Coton fanciers describe them as “witty” companions “at times boisterous but never demanding” and “naturally clownish and lighthearted
column11: ” who possess a “remarkably gentle
column12: sympathetic awareness.” Amusing traits of these long-lived jesters include unique vocalizations and a knack for walking on their hind legs. The Coton de Tulear
column13: “Royal Dog of Madagascar
column14: ” is a bright
column15: happy-go-lucky companion dog whose favorite activities include clowning
column16: cavorting
column17: and following their special human around the house. The Coton is small but robustly sturdy."

column5: "The word “icon” is terribly overworked
column6: but the Dachshund—with his unmistakable long-backed body
column7: little legs
column8: and big personality—is truly an icon of purebred dogdom. Dachshunds can be standard-sized (usually 16 to 32 pounds) or miniature (11 pounds or under)
column9: and come in one of three coat types: smooth
column11: or longhaired.Dachshunds aren’t built for distance running
column12: leaping
column13: or strenuous swimming
column14: but otherwise these tireless hounds are game for anything. Smart and vigilant
column15: with a big-dog bark
column16: they make fine watchdogs. Bred to be an independent hunter of dangerous prey
column17: they can be brave to the point of rashness
column19: but their endearing nature and unique look has won millions of hearts the world over. The famously long
column23: vivacious personality of the Dachshund have made him a superstar of the canine kingdom. Dachshunds come in two sizes and in three coat types of various colors and patterns."

column5: "The Dalmatian’s delightful
column6: eye-catching spots of black or liver adorn one of the most distinctive coats in the animal kingdom. Beneath the spots is a graceful
column7: elegantly proportioned trotting dog standing between 19 and 23 inches at the shoulder. Dals are muscular
column8: built to go the distance; the powerful hindquarters provide the drive behind the smooth
column9: effortless gait.The Dal was originally bred to guard horses and coaches
column10: and some of the old protective instinct remains. Reserved and dignified
column11: Dals can be aloof with strangers and are dependable watchdogs. With their preferred humans
column12: Dals are bright
column13: loyal
column14: and loving house dogs. They are strong
column15: active athletes with great stamina—a wonderful partner for runners and hikers. The dignified Dalmatian
column16: dogdom's citizen of the world
column17: is famed for his spotted coat and unique job description. During their long history
column18: these ""coach dogs"" have accompanied the horse-drawn rigs of nobles

column5: "Physical hallmarks of the Dandie Dinmont Terrier include a large head covered with profuse
column6: silky white hair; long
column7: hanging ears tipped with feathering and coming almost to a point; big
column8: round eyes full of brightness and expression; and a long
column9: low torso and short legs. The crisp body coat comes in two spicy colors: pepper (bluish black to silvery gray) and mustard (reddish brown to pale fawn).Weighing no more than 24 pounds
column10: Dandies are alert and intelligent watchdogs with a big baritone bark. Dandies enjoy romping and cuddling with kids
column11: but aren’t as hyper as some small dogs. They are terriers
column12: though
column13: with typical willfulness
column14: independence
column15: and courage. Dandie owners get best results with positive
column16: motivational training. The unique-looking Dandie Dinmont Terrier is a tough but dignified little exterminator. Sturdily built for the rigors of farm life
column17: they will agreeably adapt to city living. Dandies are compact companions blessed with a big personality."

column5: "Dobermans are compactly-built dogs—muscular
column6: fast
column7: and powerful—standing between 24 to 28 inches at the shoulder. The body is sleek but substantial
column8: and is covered with a glistening coat of black
column9: blue
column11: or fawn
column12: with rust markings. These elegant qualities
column13: combined with a noble
column14: wedge-shaped head and an easy
column15: athletic way of moving have earned Dobermans a reputation as royalty in the canine kingdom. A well-conditioned Doberman on patrol will deter all but the most foolish intruder. Sleek and powerful
column16: possessing both a magnificent physique and keen intelligence
column17: the Doberman Pinscher is one of dogkind's noblemen. This incomparably fearless and vigilant breed stands proudly among the world's finest protection dogs."

column5: "The English Foxhound is the epitome of what serious dog breeders strive for: beauty
column6: balance
column7: and utility. “Next to an old Greek statue
column8: ” a poet wrote
column9: “there are few such combinations of grace and strength as in a fine Foxhound.”These pack-oriented
column10: scent-driven hounds are gentle and sociable
column11: but rarely seen as house pets. They can be so driven by a primal instinct for pursuit that not much else
column12: including training
column13: matters to them. Owning these noble creatures is best left to huntsmen who kennel packs of hounds or to those experienced in meeting the special challenges of life with swift
column14: powerful hounds hardwired for the chase. The English Foxhound is a substantial galloping hound of great stamina. His long legs are straight as a gatepost
column15: and just as sturdy. The back is perfectly level. And the chest is very deep
column16: “girthing” as much as 31 inches on a hound measuring 24 inches at the shoulder
column17: ensuring plenty of lung power for a grueling day’s hunt."

column5: "English Setters are elegant but solid dogs of beauty and charm. The word “belton
column6: ” unique to the breed
column7: describes the speckled coat patterns of colors that sound good enough to eat: liver
column8: lemon
column9: and orange among them. Under the showy coat is a well-balanced hunter standing about 25 inches at the shoulder.A graceful neck carries a long
column11: and dark brown eyes convey a soft expression. The merry English Setter is known as the gentleman of the dog world but is game and boisterous at play. English Setters get on well with other dogs and people. A veteran all-breed dog handler says
column12: “As a breed to share one’s life and living space with
column13: no other breed gives me more pleasure than the English Setter.” The English Setter is a medium-sized sporting dog of sweet temper and show-stopping good looks. It is one of the AKC’s four British setters created to work on the distinctly different terrains of England
column14: Ireland
column15: and Scotland."
column16: "Friendly
column17: Mellow

column5: "Built for long days in the field
column6: English Springer Spaniels are tough
column7: muscular hunters standing 19 to 20 inches at the shoulder and weighing between 40 and 50 pounds. The double coat comes in several colors and patterns
column8: the ears are long and lush
column9: and the kindly
column10: trusting expression of the eyes is a cherished hallmark of the breed. Springers move with a smooth
column11: ground-covering stride.Bred to work closely with humans
column12: Springers are highly trainable people-pleasers. They crave company and are miserable when neglected.Polite dogs
column13: Springers are good with kids and their fellow mammals. They are eager to join in any family activity. Long walks
column14: games of chase and fetch
column15: and swimming are favorite pastimes of these rugged spaniels. The English Springer Spaniel is a sweet-faced
column16: lovable bird dog of great energy
column17: stamina
column18: and brains. Sport hunters cherish the duality of working Springers: handsome
column20: and trusty hunting buddies on weekends."

column5: "The ETS is a square
column6: snub-nosed toy weighing no more than 14 pounds. The large domed head—with its long and lush ears
column7: dark melting eyes
column8: and chubby cheeks—is a famous breed trait. The profuse coat comes in four varieties
column9: each with its own proper name: red and white (Blenheim); black and tan (King Charles); white
column11: and tan (Prince Charles); and a solid red (Ruby). Blenheims often have a red mark
column12: the “Blenheim Spot
column13: ” on top of the head.The ETS
column14: like many toy breeds kept by royals
column15: came to assume the personalities of their aristocratic owners. They can be proud and willful
column16: and extremely discriminating in their choice of friends. With their favored humans
column17: they are affectionate at home and exuberant and curious at play. The merry English Toy Spaniel was bred to be the companion of kings. But ETS are spaniels first and pampered lapdogs second
column18: and beneath the patrician exterior beats the heart of a real doggy dog—bright

column5: "Field Spaniels bear a family resemblance to Cocker
column6: Springer
column7: and Sussex spaniels. The distinctive glossy coat is either black
column8: some shade of liver
column9: or combinations of the two. They stand 17 or 18 inches at the shoulder and should present the picture of well-balanced
column10: moderately proportioned hunting companions. The long
column11: feathery ears frame a facial expression conveying a grave
column12: gentle intelligence.Field Spaniels are sweet
column13: sensitive souls with just enough independence to make life interesting. They are trustworthy with kids
column14: tolerant of their fellow mammals
column15: and responsive to training. The U.S. breed standard calls these tranquil house dogs “unusually docile
column16: ” but they are nonetheless playful and enjoy a good backyard romp. The sweet and sensitive Field Spaniel is famously docile
column17: but vigorous and game for anything when at play or in the field. These close cousins to Cocker Spaniels and Springer Spaniels may be small in number

column5: finnish spitz
column6: "The balanced
column7: squarely symmetrical Finnish Spitz will stand not more than 20 inches at the shoulder and are easily recognized by their  foxy face and prick ears projecting a lively expression
column8: and a curving plumed tail. Their dense coat of glorious golden-red which is never monochromatic gives them the Finnish Spitz “Glow.” Finkies or Finns
column9: as they are nicknamed
column10: move with a bold and brisk gait.Finkies  make excellent alertdogs
column11: wary but not shy with strangers. This is a vocal breed – in Finland
column12: owners hold contests to crown a “King Barker” – and true Finn lovers are more delighted than annoyed by their breed’s yodeling and range of vocalization. Finkies are eager canine athletes and eye-catching show dogs known to be smart
column13: sensitive
column14: and captivating companions. The lively Finnish Spitz
column15: the flame-colored
column16: foxy-faced breed from the “Land of 60
column17: 000 Lakes
column18: ” is a small but fearless hunting dog whose unique style of tracking and indicating quarry has earned him the nickname the “Barking Bird Dog.”"

column7: but in silhouette they present a leaner
column8: more elegant look.Dogdom’s champion tail-waggers

column7: belly

column11: from the compact Scottish Terrier to the majestic Scottish Deerhound

column8: with the smooth and easy stride of born noblemen. The coat comes in different colors and patterns

column5: "Greyhounds are the essence of the dog breeder’s credo “Form follows function.” From the narrow
column6: aerodynamic skull to the shock-absorbing pads of the feet
column7: Greyhounds are perfectly constructed for high-speed pursuit. The lean beauty of the Greyhound’s “inverted S” shape
column8: created by the deep chest curving gently into a tightly tucked waist
column9: has been an object of fascination for artists
column11: and kings for as long as human beings have called themselves civilized. Greyhounds are the template from which other coursing hounds have been struck. The champion sprinter of dogdom
column12: the Greyhound dog breed is a gentle
column13: noble
column14: and sweet-tempered companion with an independent spirit. For thousands of years these graceful hounds have been an object of fascination for artists
column15: poets
column16: and kings."

column5: "Distinctive features of the Havanese include a curled-over tail and a gorgeous silky coat
column6: which comes in a variety of colors. Some owners enjoy cording the coat
column7: in the manner of a Puli
column8: and others clip it short to reduce grooming time. Happily
column9: Havenese are just as cute no matter what hairdo you give them.Their small but sturdy bodies
column11: and social skills make Havanese an ideal city dog

column5: "The Irish Setter has been described by its partisans as the most beautiful of dog breeds. Standing more than two feet at the shoulder
column6: with a substantial yet elegant build
column7: the Irish is famed for a brilliant coat of mahogany or chestnut. Long
column8: sinewy legs and powerful rear drive help to place the Irish among the swiftest of all sporting dogs.The Irish Setter’s lovable personality has endeared the breed to sportsmen and pet owners for more than 200 years. Irish are outgoing dogs who enjoy making friends. These rambunctious redheads are big kids at heart
column9: but they are eager to please and will respond to patient
column10: positive training. They are said to be bold and rugged hunting partners
column11: with a devil-may-care approach to their work. The Irish Setter is a high-spirited gundog known for grace
column12: swiftness
column13: and a flashy red coat. They are famously good family dogs: sweet-tempered companions for the folks
column14: and rollicking playmates and tennis-ball fetchers for the children."

column5: "Standing 21 to 24 inches at the shoulder and weighing 55 to 65 pounds
column6: the Irish Water Spaniel straddles the line between “medium” and “large” dogs on our scale of size. Among its distinguishing characteristics are a crisply curled
column7: liver-colored
column8: waterproof coat; a tapered “rat tail”; and a cleanly chiseled head crowned with a topknot of long
column9: loose curls. The IWS moves with a smooth ground-covering gait
column10: enabling him to put in a long day’s work in the field. The tallest of the AKC’s spaniels
column11: the Irish Water Spaniel is instantly recognizable by its crisply curled coat and tapering “rat tail.” Among the champion swimmers of dogdom
column12: the alert and inquisitive IWS is hardworking and brave in the field
column13: and playfully affectionate at home."
column14: "Playful
column15: Hardworking
column16: Brave"

column5: "The amiable Irish Wolfhound is an immense
column6: muscular hound gracefully built along classic Greyhound lines
column7: capable of great speed at the gallop. A male might stand nearly 3 feet at the shoulder and weigh up to 180 pounds. Females will run smaller but are still a whole lot of hound. The rough
column8: hard coat comes in many colors
column9: including white
column11: brindle
column12: red
column13: black
column14: and fawn.IWs are too serene to be fierce guard dogs
column15: but just the sight of them is enough to deter intruders. IWs are characteristically patient with kids
column16: though animals their size should be supervised around small children. Owning an Irish Wolfhound is a unique
column17: rewarding experience—but acquiring a giant galloping hound is a commitment as big as the dog itself. The calm
column19: and kindly Irish Wolfhound is the tallest of all AKC breeds. Once fearless big-game hunters capable of dispatching a wolf in single combat
column20: Wolfhounds today are the most serene and agreeable of companions."

column5: "Our Hungarian-language tip of the day: The plural of Komondor is Komondorok. Now
column6: let’s take a look at the dog. What we see is a large and powerful guardian covered in profuse white cords. A big male can stand more than 27.5 inches and weigh over 100 pounds
column7: with heavy bone
column8: a deep chest
column9: and lots of muscle. Despite their brawn Komondorok are agile and light-footed
column10: and move with long strides. With their unique look
column11: it’s impossible to mistake Koms for anything else. A powerfully large Hungarian flock guardian covered in profuse white cords from head to tail
column12: the Komondor is among the world’s most recognizable breeds. The independent and protective Kom requires a firm
column13: experienced hand at training."

column5: "For the uninitiated
column6: a face-to-face encounter with these black-masked giants can be startling. A male stands at least 30 inches at the shoulder and can outweigh many a full-grown man. The rectangular body is deep and thickly muscled
column7: covered by a short double coat of fawn
column8: apricot
column9: or brindle stripes. The head is broad and massive
column10: and a wrinkled forehead accentuates an alert
column11: kindly expression. Mastiffs are patient
column12: lovable companions and guardians who take best to gentle training. Eternally loyal Mastiffs are protective of family
column13: and a natural wariness of strangers makes early training and socialization essential. Mastiffs are magnificent pets
column14: but acquiring a powerful giant-breed dog is commitment not to be taken lightly. The colossal Mastiff belongs to a canine clan as ancient as civilization itself. A massive
column15: heavy-boned dog of courage and prodigious strength
column16: the Mastiff is docile and dignified but also a formidable protector of those they hold dear."
column17: "Courageous

column5: "In nearly every way the Mini is a Bull Terrier
column6: only smaller. In fact
column7: before 1991 the AKC classified the two Bullys as varieties of the same breed. Minis stand between 10 and 14 inches at the shoulder. They’re square
column8: muscular
column9: and
column11: quite strong. Their trademark is a large egg-shaped head
column12: with its dark
column13: triangular eyes that twinkle with mischief. It’s impossible to mistake the Bull Terrier breeds for any other. The coat can be pure white
column14: or white with predominate colored markings. In most every way the Miniature Bull Terrier is a Bull Terrier
column15: only smaller. These upbeat
column16: mischievous dogs come equipped with terrier fire and fearlessness. If ever a dog could claim the title “Clown Prince of Dogdom
column17: ” it’s the Mini."

column5: "Min Pins are sturdy
column6: compact dogs standing no more than 12.5 inches at the shoulder. The smooth
column7: shiny coat comes in two shades of solid red
column8: or chocolate-and-rust or black-and-rust. The dark
column9: slightly oval eyes and high-set ears help bring out a self-possessed
column10: “big dog” personality. A distinguishing characteristic is the Min Pin’s high-stepping “hackney” gait
column11: reminiscent of a hackney horse at the trot. The leggy Miniature Pinscher is known to fans as the “King of Toys.” This proud
column12: fearless
column13: fun-loving toy breed of lustrous coat and a compact
column14: wedge-shaped physique is a true personality dog
column15: known for a high-stepping “hackney” gait."

column5: "Unless you’ve been to Jurassic Park
column6: you’ve never seen anything like a Mastino. These majestic guardians of startling appearance are massive
column7: powerful dogs. The U.S. Neapolitan Mastiff Club describes their dog’s head as “astounding”—and give them credit for hitting upon just the right adjective. The profuse hanging wrinkles and folds
column8: and pendulous lips
column9: make a Mastino look like a marzipan Mastiff that’s been out in the sun too long. And yet
column10: the breed’s inner dignity and nobility can only be described as beautiful. The Neapolitan Mastiff is a huge
column11: powerful guarder whose astounding appearance has intimidated intruders since the days of ancient Rome. Wary with strangers
column12: the profusely wrinkled Mastino is sweet
column13: placid
column14: and steady among loved ones."
column15: "Loyal
column16: Dignified
column17: Watchful"

column5: "A male Newfoundland can weigh up to 150 pounds and stand 28 inches at the shoulder; females typically go 100 to 120 pounds. The Newf head is majestic
column6: the expression soft and soulful. The outer coat is flat and coarse. Colors are gray
column7: brown
column8: black
column9: and a black-and-white coat named for artist Sir Edwin Landseer
column10: who popularized the look in his paintings.The Newfie breed standard says that a sweet temperament is the “most important single characteristic of the breed.” The Newf’s sterling character is expressed in their affinity for kids. Trusting and trainable
column11: Newfs respond well to gentle guidance. These noble giants are among the world’s biggest dogs
column12: and acquiring a pet that could outweigh you comes with obvious challenges. The massive Newfoundland is a strikingly large
column13: powerful working dog of heavy bone and dignified bearing. The sweet-tempered Newfie is a famously good companion and has earned a reputation as a patient and watchful “nanny dog” for kids."
column14: "Sweet
column15: Patient
column16: Devoted"

column5: "Norfolk Terriers are among the smallest working terriers
column6: standing no higher than 10 inches at the shoulder. The coat is hard
column7: wiry
column8: and straight. They share many traits with their close cousins
column9: Norwich Terriers. To tell them apart
column10: look at the ears: The Norwich has erect
column11: pointed ears; Norfolk ears are neatly folded over.Bred to work in packs
column12: Norfolks are more gregarious than a typical terrier
column13: but they have plenty of the old terrier pep. Few Norfolks these days earn their living hunting rodents
column14: but a good one will fearlessly do so when given a chance. Norfolks bond closely
column15: sometimes jealously
column16: with their owners and make nice watchdogs. They have a reputation as a good traveler: portable
column17: adaptable
column18: and up for anything. Norfolk Terriers are little
column21: and they will gladly curl up in your lap
column22: but don’t dare call them lapdogs. Norfolks

column5: "Norwegian Elkhounds are hardy
column6: short-bodied dogs standing about 20 inches at the shoulder. They have a dense silver-gray coat and a tail curling tightly over the back. The deep chest
column7: sturdy legs
column8: and muscular thighs belong to a dog built for an honest day’s work. The eyes are a dark brown and the ears mobile and erect. Overall
column9: an Elkhound is the picture of an alert and steadfast dog of the north.Elkhounds are famously fine companions and intelligent watchdogs. Agility and herding trials are good outlets for their natural athleticism and eagerness. Reserved until introductions are made
column10: an Elkhound is a trustworthy friend ever after. These strong
column11: confident dogs are truly sensitive souls
column12: with a dash of houndy independence. The Norwegian Elkhound is a robust spitz type known for his lush silver-gray coat and dignified but friendly demeanor. The durable Elkhound is among Europe's oldest dogs. They sailed with the Vikings and figure in Norse art and legend."
column13: "Friendly
column14: Confident
column15: Dependable"

column6: "These big
column7: bouncy hounds were ideally suited for otter hunting. OHs are built to be expert swimmers
column8: from the top of their rough
column9: waterproof coat to the bottom of their big webbed feet. A broad chest and powerful shoulders allow them to swim all day without tiring. Their large black nose is amazingly sensitive and could follow an otter’s underwater scent trail over great distances. And the OH’s size and strength enabled them to take on a sharp-toothed
column10: razor-clawed otter that might weigh 20 pounds. Big
column11: boisterous
column12: and affectionate
column13: the Otterhound was bred in medieval England for the now-outlawed activity of otter hunting. This scarce breed is known for his dense shaggy coat
column14: webbed feet
column15: acute sense of smell
column16: and affinity for swimming."

column19: the Pap is truly a “doggy dog” blessed with a hardy constitution. Papillon fanciers describe their breed as happy

column6: a well-built male Pembroke presents a big dog in a small package. Short but powerful legs
column7: muscular thighs
column8: and a deep chest equip him for a hard day’s work. Built long and low
column9: Pembrokes are surprisingly quick and agile. They can be red
column11: fawn
column12: and black and tan
column13: with or without white markings.The Pembroke is a bright
column14: sensitive dog who enjoys play with his human family and responds well to training. As herders bred to move cattle
column15: they are fearless and independent. They are vigilant watchdogs
column16: with acute senses and a “big dog” bark. Families who can meet their bold but kindly Pembroke’s need for activity and togetherness will never have a more loyal
column17: loving pet. Among the most agreeable of all small housedogs
column18: the Pembroke Welsh Corgi is a strong
column20: and lively little herder who is affectionate and companionable without being needy. They are one of the world's most popular herding breeds."

column5: "The Pomeranian combines a tiny body (no more than seven pounds) and a commanding big-dog demeanor. The abundant double coat
column6: with its frill extending over the chest and shoulders
column7: comes in almost two dozen colors
column8: and various patterns and markings
column9: but is most commonly seen in orange or red.Alert and intelligent
column10: Pomeranians are easily trained and make fine watchdogs and perky pets for families with children old enough to know the difference between a toy dog and a toy. Poms are active but can be exercised with indoor play and short walks
column11: so they are content in both the city and suburbs. They will master tricks and games with ease
column12: though their favorite activity is providing laughs and companionship to their special human. The tiny Pomeranian
column13: long a favorite of royals and commoners alike
column14: has been called the ideal companion. The glorious coat
column15: smiling
column16: foxy face
column17: and vivacious personality have helped make the Pom one of the world's most popular toy breeds."

column5: "The Portuguese Water Dog is super-smart and very biddable—meaning he’s easy to train and eager to please. The breed can be groomed in two styles: The retriever clip (the entire coat is clipped to one inch in length
column6: with the tail tip at full length) or the more check-me-out lion clip
column7: where the coat on the hindquarters and muzzle is clipped down to the skin. The bright and biddable Portuguese Water Dog was bred to be an all-around fisherman’s helper. The robust
column8: medium-sized body is covered by a coat of tight
column9: low-shedding curls. They are eager and athletic companions built for water work."
column11: Adventurous
column12: Athletic"

column5: "The Pug’s motto is the Latin phrase “multum in parvo” (a lot in a little)—an apt description of this small but muscular breed. They come in three colors: silver or apricot-fawn with a black face mask
column6: or all black. The large round head
column7: the big
column8: sparkling eyes
column9: and the wrinkled brow give Pugs a range of human-like expressions—surprise
column11: curiosity—that have delighted owners for centuries.Pug owners say their breed is the ideal house dog. Pugs are happy in the city or country
column12: with kids or old folks
column13: as an only pet or in a pack. They enjoy their food
column14: and care must be taken to keep them trim. They do best in moderate climates—not too hot
column15: not too cold—but
column16: with proper care
column17: Pugs can be their adorable selves anywhere. Once the mischievous companion of Chinese emperors
column18: and later the mascot of Holland’s royal House of Orange
column19: the small but solid Pug is today adored by his millions of fans around the world. Pugs live to love and to be loved in return."

column5: "First
column6: there are those dreadlocks
column7: the instantly recognizable feature of the Puli (pronounced “Poo-lee”—”Pulik” is the plural). The coat’s naturally occurring cords are wooly
column8: dense
column9: and weatherproof. Either corded or brushed out
column10: Puli coats require lots of attention. Under the dreads there’s a compact but powerful dog
column11: standing 16 to 17 inches at the shoulder. Pulik are remarkably agile and light on their feet
column12: earning a reputation as the “acrobat of the dog world.” No other breed can be mistaken for the Puli
column13: a compact but powerful herder covered from head to tail with profuse
column14: naturally occurring cords. Bred to work closely with humans
column15: these agile and faithful little dynamos are quick learners."

column5: "Redbones are medium-to-large hound dogs whose muscles undulate beneath a sleek and stunning red coat. The overall impression is that a master sculptor carved them from blocks of the finest mahogany. The classically houndy head is flanked by ears long enough to reach the nose. Dreamy brown eyes give the face an expression described by the breed’s devotees as “pleading.”Bred to work on all kinds of punishing terrain
column6: Redbones are fast and surefooted and move with a proud
column7: determined gait. The streamlined Redbone Coonhound
column8: an American original
column9: is even-tempered
column11: and kindly at home but a tiger on the trail. Vigorous activities like hunting and swimming between long periods of rest is the rhythm of coonhound life."
column12: "Even-Tempered
column13: Amiable
column14: Eager to Please"

column5: "Beneath the Ridgeback’s trademark ridge is a whole lot of hound: Ridgebacks are fast and powerful athletes who can weigh between 70 and 85 pounds
column6: and oftentimes more. They come in only one color – wheaten – which spans every shade seen in a wheat field
column7: from pale flaxen to the burnished red of a maturing crop. Ridgebacks also have two nose colors: black and the less commonly seen brown.The formidable Ridgeback can be strong willed
column8: independent
column9: and sometimes domineering. Ridgebacks must be guided with a firm but fair hand from puppyhood. They are faithful friends
column10: protective of their loved ones and meltingly affectionate with those whom they trust. Still
column11: a Ridgeback can be too much hound for the novice dog owner. The Rhodesian Ridgeback is an all-purpose “Renaissance hound” whose hallmark is the ridge
column12: or stripe of backward-growing hair
column13: on his back. Though the breed was made famous in its native Africa for its skill at tracking and baying – but never
column14: ever killing – lions
column15: today Ridgebacks are cherished family dogs whose owners must be prepared to deal with their independence and strong prey drive."
column16: "Affectionate
column17: Dignified

column5: "A male Rottweiler will stand anywhere from 24 to 27 muscular inches at the shoulder; females run a bit smaller and lighter. The glistening
column6: short black coat with smart rust markings add to the picture of imposing strength. A thickly muscled hindquarters powers the Rottie’s effortless trotting gait.A well-bred and properly raised Rottie will be calm and confident
column7: courageous but not unduly aggressive. The aloof demeanor these world-class guardians present to outsiders belies the playfulness
column8: and downright silliness
column9: that endear Rotties to their loved ones. (No one told the Rottie he’s not a toy breed
column10: so he is liable plop onto your lap for a cuddle.) Early training and socialization will harness a Rottie’s territorial instincts in a positive way. The Rottweiler is a robust working breed of great strength descended from the mastiffs of the Roman legions. A gentle playmate and protector within the family circle
column11: the Rottie observes the outside world with a self-assured aloofness."
column12: "Loyal
column13: Loving
column14: Confident Guardian"

column5: "The beauty of Salukis has been a thing of wonder for thousands of years. They’re slim and leggy
column6: but very strong and perfectly balanced
column7: like a great athlete or dancer. Males can stand between 23 and 28 inches at the shoulder; females can be much shorter. They come in a many colors and patterns. Their large
column8: oval-shaped eyes are warm and intelligent.Salukis are highly adaptable
column9: able to live and work in any climate. They’re magnificent animals
column10: but owning them comes with many special challenges. Among the world’s oldest breeds
column11: the slim but rugged Saluki was the hunting hound of kings for thousands of years. Salukis are swift and agile sprinters who love a good chase. They make gentle
column12: dignified
column13: and independent but loyal pets."

column5: "Samoyeds
column6: the smiling sledge dogs
column7: were bred for hard work in the world’s coldest locales. In the Siberian town of Oymyakon
column8: for instance
column9: temperatures of minus-60 degrees are common. The Sammy’s famous white coat is thick enough to protect against such brutal conditions.Powerful
column11: tireless
column12: impervious to cold—Sammies are drop-dead gorgeous but highly functional. Even their most delightful feature
column13: a perpetual smile
column14: has a practical function: The mouth’s upturned corners keep Sammies from drooling
column15: preventing icicles from forming on the face.A Sammy sentenced to solitary confinement in the yard is a miserable—and destructive—creature. These are smart
column16: social
column17: mischievous dogs who demand love and attention. Sammies need a very firm but loving hand in training. As pack animals
column18: they must learn early who the alpha dog is—and the alpha dog must be you. The Samoyed is a substantial but graceful dog standing anywhere from 19 to a bit over 23 inches at the shoulder. Powerful
column20: with a thick all-white coat impervious to cold—Sammies are perfectly beautiful but highly functional. Even their most delightful feature
column22: has a practical function: The upturned corners of the mouth keep Sammies from drooling
column23: preventing icicles from forming on the face."

column6: medium-sized Siberian Husky’s almond-shaped eyes can be either brown or blue—and sometimes one of each—and convey a keen but amiable and even mischievous expression. Quick and nimble-footed
column7: Siberians are known for their powerful but seemingly effortless gait. Tipping the scales at no more than 60 pounds
column8: they are noticeably smaller and lighter than their burly cousin
column9: the Alaskan Malamute. In fact
column10: breeders and fanciers prefer the moniker Siberians over huskies
column11: as the latter suggests a bigger
column12: brawnier dog than what is the standard for the breed.As born pack dogs
column13: Siberians enjoy family life and get on well with other dogs; their innate friendliness render them indifferent watchdogs. This breed is also energetic and can’t resist chasing small animals
column14: so secure running room is a must. An attractive feature of the breed: Siberians are naturally clean
column15: with little doggy odor. The Siberian Husky
column16: a thickly coated
column17: compact sled dog of medium size and great endurance
column18: was developed to work in packs
column19: pulling light loads at moderate speeds over vast frozen expanses. This northern breed is friendly

column5: "The Vizsla is easily recognized by his sleek golden-rust coat. They can stand between 21 to 24 inches at the shoulder and are the picture of a lean
column6: light-footed hunter’s companion. The long
column7: silky ears frame a facial expression that is sensitive and loving around the house and intense when at work. As a hunter expected to work closely with humans
column8: Vizslas form a tight bond with their owners and hate to be left alone.Athletes of many talents
column9: Vizslas excel at various sports and activities. They are eager and graceful trotters of great stamina
column10: making them ideal jogging or biking companions. An expert on the breed tells us
column11: “If you don’t have the time to encourage this breed’s full use of its brain
column12: you’re wasting a good dog.” The Vizsla is a versatile
column13: red-coated gundog built for long days in the field. For centuries
column14: these rugged but elegant athletes have been the pride of Hungarian sportsmen and their popularity in America increases with each passing year."
column15: "Affectionate
column16: Gentle
column17: Energetic"

column8: with maybe a small white spot on the chest. The face

column11: the breed presents a picture of streamlined grace and balance. A well-conditioned Weimaraner on point is a breathtaking sight.Weimaraners are excellent with kids and yearn to be full-fledged family members. Easy grooming

column13: a loving nature
column14: and a can-do-attitude make them excellent pets

column16: Germany’s sleek and swift “Gray Ghost

column21: along with lots of quality time with their humans."

The beautiful coat isn’t just ornamental—it’s a waterproof
column7: weatherproof
column8: and thornproof suit that enables Welshies to show off their renowned versatility in all climates and on all terrains. The Welsh Springer Spaniel is a vigorous

column10: known for versatility in the field
column11: companionability at home
column12: and dashing good looks anywhere. The Welshie is among Britain's oldest sporting breeds."

column5: "The Yorkshire Terrier is a compact
column6: toy-size terrier of no more than seven pounds whose crowning glory is a floor-length
column7: silky coat of steel blue and a rich golden tan.Don’t let the Yorkie’s daintiness fool you. Tenacious
column8: feisty
column9: brave
column11: the Yorkie exhibits all the traits of a true terrier. Often named the most popular dog breed in various American cities
column12: Yorkies pack lots of big-town attitude into a small but self-important package. They are favorites of urbanites the world over.Yorkies are long-lived and low-allergen (the coat is more like human hair than animal fur)
column13: and they make fine little watchdogs. This is a true “personality breed
column14: ” providing years of laughs
column15: love
column16: and close companionship. Beneath the dainty
column17: glossy
column18: floor-length coat of a Yorkshire Terrier beats the heart of a feisty
column19: old-time terrier. Yorkies earned their living as ratters in mines and mills long before they became the beribboned lapdogs of Victorian ladies."
